questions.explanation: Orchidopexy is ideally performed before the boy reaches 12 months of age.Orchidopexy is done before 12 months of age to avoid the following complications:• Infertility•Malignancy (Risk may still exist post surgery)• Hernia•• Testicular torsion• InfectionThe management for undescended testes that are not palpable is:Management of Undescended testisUnilateralnonpalpableLaparoscopyBilateralnonpalpableBlind-endingvesselsVessels exitinginternal ringIntra-abdominaltestisNoresponseMonorchiaInguinalexplorationhCGIncreasedtestosterone(and increasedFSH, LH)LaparoscopyAnorchia± exploration+ exciseremnantOrchiopexyOrchiectomyFowler-Stephensorchiopexy(laparoscopic or open)MARROW

questions.question: A 1-year-old child was brought to the OPD as the mother noticed that the scrotum containedonly one testicle. On examination, the testis is not palpable in the inguinal region orabdomen. A diagnostic laparoscopy reveals abdominal testes and orchiopexy is done. Whichof the following tumors is most likely to develop in this patient?
questions.explanation: The tumor most likely to develop in this patient is seminoma.The tumor that develops most commonly in undesceded testes is germ cell tumor in situ orintratubular germ cell tumor. It commonly progresses into seminomas.In patients with a nonpalpable testicle, diagnostic laparoscopy is performed. If testis is still notvisualised, the spermatic cord or testicular artery is traced at the deep inguinal ring to locate it.If a blind ending spermatic cord is found instead, vanishing testis syndrome (or testicularregression syndrome) is suspected. It is the partial or total absence of testicular tissue often due toan ischemic event in foetal life.991The testis once found can be delivered into the scrotum, and an orchidopexy is performed.Management of Undescended testisUnilateralnonpalpableLaparoscopyBilateralnonpalpableBlind-endingvesselsVessels exitinginternal ringIntra-abdominaltestisNoresponseMonorchiaInguinalexplorationhCGIncreasedtestosterone(and increasedFSH, LH)Anorchia± exciseremnantLaparoscopyexplorationOrchiopexyOrchiectomyFowler-Stephensorchiopexy(laparoscopic or open)MARROW

questions.question: 981A newborn was diagnosed with undescended testes. Due to the intra-abdominal location ofthe testes, a two-stage Stephen-Fowler's orchiopexy was planned. Which of the following isperformed during the first stage of this procedure?
questions.explanation: In the first stage of a two-stage Stephens-Fowler approach, the testicular vessels are clipped.Clipping of the testicular artery promotes neo vasculogenesis along the vas deferens. It does notresult in ischemia of the testis due to the presence of collaterals from the cremasteric artery andthe artery to the ductus deferens (deferential artery).Several months later, after collaterals are established, the second stage is performed during whichthe testis and its new blood supply is mobilized into the scrotum.Stephen-Fowler's approach is done when an intra abdominal testes is located too far to reach thescrotum. Alternatively, Silbar's orchiopexy may be done. In this procedure, microvascularanastomosis of the testicular vessels with internal illiac vessels is done after the testis is mobilisedto the scrotum.

questions.question: What is the most common cause of testicular torsion?

options.B: Presence of remnant of mullerian duct
options.D: Pedicle between epididymis and body of testis

questions.explanation: High investment of the tunica vaginalis is the most common cause of torsion of testis. It causesthe testes to hang within the tunica like a clapper in a bell. This is the most common cause oftesticular torsion in adolescents.Bell clapper testes are typically bilateral. The image below shows the bell-clapper deformity of thetestes:992MVasdeferensMBell Clapper testesNormal lieBell Clapper testesOMARROWSpermaticcordEpididymisTestisTunicavaginalisTunicaVaginalisOther abnormalities that cause torsion of the testes:• Inversion of the testis: The testis is rotated so that it lies transversely or upside down.Pedicle between epididymis and body of testis: Separation of the epididymis from the body of thetestis by a pedicle allows torsion of the testis on the pedicle that connects the testis with theepididymis.An appendix testis is a small vestigial appendage located on the upper pole of the testis. Twistingof the appendage causes testicular appendix torsion. In it, a classic blue dot sign is seen on theupper pole of the testis. It is seen as a hard tender nodule with a blue discoloration on thesuperior aspect of the testis. This is a remnant of the Mullerian duct, that regresses ondevelopment.The image below shows the blue dot sign on the testis:993

questions.question: A 14-year-old boy presents with acute onset of pain in his scrotum. He previously had similarpain that would subside spontaneously but the pain this time is unbearable. Physicalexamination shows a swollen erythematous scrotum. Cremasteric reflex is absent. What is thenext best step in management?
questions.explanation: The given clinical vignette is suggestive of testicular torsion. In cases of high clinical suspicion, thenext best step is to explore surgically.Clinical features of testicular torsion are painful scrotal swelling, erythema, nausea, and vomiting,testis seems high in the scrotum and the twisted cord can sometimes be palpated.Signs seen on torsion of the testis are:• Deming's sign: Spasm of the cremaster muscle due to twisting of the spermatic cord causes theaffected testis to be positioned higher than the normal testis.• Angell's sign: The testis on the normal side lies horizontally because of the mesorchium betweenthe testis and epididymis.•Cremastic reflex: Absent on the side of the affected testisDoppler ultrasound scanning can confirm the absence of the blood supply to the affected testis,but the false positives are high and hence it is not routinely recommended.Manual detorsion of the testes is usually difficult because of acute pain during manipulation.Nonoperative manual detorsion is not a substitute for surgical exploration.

questions.question: A child presents with pain and swelling in the right side of his scrotum and testicular torsionis suspected. Which is the most appropriate management?

options.A: Immediate exploration on both symptomatic and asymptomatic side
options.B: Immediate exploration on symptomatic side only
options.C: Delayed exploration on both symptomatic and asymptomatic side982
options.D: Delayed exploration on symptomatic side only

questions.explanation: In a case of suspected testicular torsion, immediate exploration needs to be done on both thesymptomatic as well as the asymptomatic side. After the de-torsion, the adequacy of the bloodflow has to be assessed by Doppler.In testicular torsion, the blood supply to the testicle is compromised due to the twisting of thespermatic cord within the tunica vaginalis, resulting in ischemia of the epididymis and the testis.The patient usually presents with acute onset pain and swelling of the scrotum. On examination,the cremasteric reflex is lost, and the scrotum looks asymmetrical.Prehn's sign is used to differentiate epididymitis from testicular torsion. Prehn's sign is said to bepositive when the pain gets relieved on lifting the testis, and it is seen in epididymo-orchitis.At the time of surgical exploration, contralateral testes also must be explored and fixed to thedartos fascia in order to prevent possible torsion occurring in this testes.More than 80% of the testis can be salvaged if surgery is performed within 6 hours. If the testis isfound to be necrosed on scrotal exploration, orchidectomy of the necrosed testis and orchidopexyof the contralateral testis is done.

questions.question: A young man presents to the emergency with a painful scrotum. On examination, the patientis febrile and a Prehn's sign is positive. What is the most likely cause of the patient'scondition?
questions.explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of acute epididymitis.994A positive Prehn's sign is used to differentiate epididymis from testicular torsion. A Prehn's sign issaid to be positive when the pain gets relieved on lifting the testis. If it persists, it is likely to betesticular torsion.Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause of acute epididymitis in young, sexually activemales. In older men(>40yrs) with bladder outflow obstruction, epididymitis results fromurinary infection, most commonly due to Escherichia coli.Acute epididymitis is managed by antibiotics and scrotal support.

questions.question: A young male patient presented with painless swelling of the scrotum. Examination revealeda firm, enlarged epididymis along with beading of the vas deferens. Testes were normal. Whatis the next best step in management?

options.B: Send urine or semen for PCR

questions.explanation: In the given scenario, a firm enlarged epididymis, beading of the vas deferens, and a normal testison palpation indicate secondary tubercular epididymo-orchitis. The next best step is confirmationwith polymerase chain reaction (PCR).Beading of the vas deferens is due to subepithelial tubercle formation and is specific to genitaltuberculosis.A scrotal USG will reveal an enlarged epididymis but does not have diagnostic value. Chest,kidney, and upper urinary tract imaging may reveal a primary focus.Tuberculous epididymo-orchitis is usually secondary and resolves once the primary focus istreated. Hence, a course of anti-tubercular therapy must be completed even if there is no evidenceof disease elsewhere.If resolution does not occur within two months, epididymectomy or orchidectomy is advisable.

questions.question: A 57-year-old diabetic patient presented with a painful, malodorous, discolored scrotum asshown in the image. The patient was febrile and in extreme pain. Which of the followingstatements is true about his condition?983

options.B: Managed by antibiotics and scrotal support
options.C: Staphylococcus is the most common causative organism
options.D: The condition is usually self limitingDAILYROUNDS

questions.explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of Fournier's gangrene in which the testis is classically spared.It lies naked following debridement of the gangrenous skin and is tucked subcutaneously into thethigh. It is also called "shameful exposure of the testis."Fournier's gangrene is a surgical emergency. It is a life-threatening disease, with a mortality ofover 40% even with treatment. It is due to a mixed infection of both aerobic and anaerobicbacterial flora.Concurrent illnesses that diminish the host defense, especially diabetes mellitus and alcoholism,predispose patients to the development of Fournier's gangrene.It is managed by debridement, wide surgical excision, IV fluids, and antibiotics.

questions.question: A 24-year-old presents with a scrotal swelling as shown in the image. The swelling isbrilliantly transilluminant and the testes cannot be palpated separately. Which additionalclinical finding is most likely to be present?
questions.explanation: The scrotal swelling is most likely a hydrocele. Due to the movement of fluid, a fluctuation test ispositive.995Hydrocoele is an accumulation of fluid within the tunica vaginalis. It is brilliantlytransilluminating and testes will not be separately palpable. As it arises in the scrotum, it ispossible to get above the swelling. It is irreducible and cough impulse is absent.A USG will show anechoic reflection due to fluid collection.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common cause of a secondary hydrocele ?
questions.explanation: A secondary hydrocele is most commonly caused by an acute or chronic epididymo-orchitis. Othercauses of secondary hydrocele include torsion of the testis and testicular tumors.Primary vaginal hydroceleDue to defective absorption of fluidTense swellingTestis not palpable separatelyTransillumination positive (clear fluid present)Secondary vaginal hydroceleDue to increased secretion offluidLax swellingTestis palpable separatelyTransillumination negative (turbid fluid present)

questions.question: A patient with hydrocele is scheduled for Lord's plication. Which of the following is falseregarding the procedure?The procedure can be performed under local anesthesiab) Increased risk of hematoma formation as compared to Jaboulay'sc) Preferred for small to medium sized swellingsd) Tunica vaginalis is bunched to obliterate the hydrocoele sacQuestion 14:A 32-year-old male patient presented with a scrotal swelling. On examination, the testis is feltseparate from the scrotal swelling and the swelling is brilliantly transilluminant, as shown inthe image below. What is the probable diagnosis?985
questions.explanation: Lord's plication has a lower risk of hematoma formation as compared to Jaboulay's procedure.Hydrocele may be managed surgically by various techniques. Lord's plication and Jaboulay'seversion of the sac are most commonly performed.Jaboulay's eversion of the sac is preferred for large hydroceles. In this method, the tunicavaginalis sac is everted around the testis. Although it has a shorter operative time, the risk ofhematoma formation is more.Congenital hydroceles are managed by a herniotomy.

questions.question: A 33-year-old man was referred to the surgery OPD from the infertility clinic. On inspection,the scrotum appeared as in the image. On palpation, a bag of worms sensation was felt. Whatis the appropriate management?
questions.explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of a varicocele. As this patient is young and infertile,varicocelectomy is indicated and a Palomo procedure may be performed.Varicocele may present with a dull aching scrotal pain and enlargement. Additionally, patients.may have infertility. A bag of worms, which gets prominent on Valsalva's maneuver is palpateddue to the engorged pampiniform plexus.Often, patients may be asymptomatic and do not require treatment.Left-sided varicocele is more common. Isolated right-sided varicocele should always raisesuspicion of renal cell carcinoma.(Note: Varicoceles occurs on left side more commonly as the left spermatic vein opens at sharpangle to the left renal vein, whereas, on the right side, the right spermatic vein opens into a largerInferior vena cava and an isolated Right-sided varicocele may indicate a tumour that compressesthe venous return in the inferior vena cava)Treatment of young patients includes surgical ligation of the gonadal vein. It may be achievedthrough embolectomy or varicocelectomy. Approaches to varicocelectomy are:•• Inguinal ( Ivanisevic method)997• Retroperitoneal (Palomo procedure)• Natural orifice transluminal endoscopic surgery through the transvesical routeIn older patients, NSAIDs and scrotal support are adequate.Grades of varicoceleGrade 1Varicocele only palpable on Valsalva's maneuverGrade 2Varicocele palpable withoutValsalva's maneuverGrade 3Varicocele is seen on inspection of the testis

questions.question: Which of the following is not a risk factor for developing testicular carcinoma?
questions.explanation: Benzopyrene exposure is not associated with an increased risk of developing testicular cancer butwith an increased risk of developing scrotal carcinoma.Shale oil exposure (a petroleum byproduct) is also associated with an increased incidence ofscrotal carcinoma.Undescended testes, history of contralateral testicular tumor, and Klinefelter's syndrome areknown to increase one's risk to develop testicular cancer.Note: Patients with Klinefelter's syndrome also have an increased risk of developing extragonadalgerm cell tumors.

questions.question: Which among the following are germ-cell tumors?
questions.explanation: Germ-cell tumors (90-95%) include seminoma, embryonal cell carcinoma, yolk-sac tumor,teratoma, and choriocarcinoma.Leydig and Sertoli cell tumors are non-germ-cell tumors.

questions.question: A 45-year-old male patient who presented with a scrotal swelling underwent an orchidectomy.The image below shows the histopathology findings. What is your diagnosis?987
questions.explanation: Based on the gross and microscopic appearance of the specimen, the diagnosis is seminoma.The gross specimen shows a well-circumscribed, pale, gray-white, fleshy, homogenous mass, witha lobulated cut surface, usually devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis. Histopathology shows uniformtumor cells with abundant clear cytoplasm, distinct cell borders, and large central nuclei. There isa sparse lymphocytic infiltrate. Classically, they have a fried egg appearance.Other options:998Option B: Yolk-sac tumor has a yellowish-white, mucinous appearance. Histologically, they aretypically composed of a lace-like (reticular) network of medium-sized cuboidal, flattened, orspindled cells, which generally show less cytologic atypia than embryonal carcinoma. Inapproximately 50% of tumors, structures resembling endodermal sinuses (Schiller-Duval bodies)may be seen; these consist of a mesodermal core with a central capillary and a visceral andparietal layer of cells resembling primitive glomeruli.2 36.Option C: Embryonal cell carcinoma appears variegated with foci of hemorrhage or necrosis.Histologically, the cells grow in alveolar or tubular patterns, sometimes with papillary folds. Moreundifferentiated lesions may display sheets of cells with cleft-like spaces. The neoplastic cells havean epithelial appearance, are large and anaplastic, and have hyperchromatic nuclei withprominent nucleoli. The cell borders are usually indistinct, and there is considerable variation incell and nuclear size and shape (pleomorphism). Mitotic figures and tumor giant cells arefrequently seen.999Option D: Teratomas also have a variegated appearance but have cysts reflecting the multiplicityof tissue types. Histologically, collections of differentiated cells or organoid structures originatingin all 3 germ layers can be seen. Elements may be mature (resembling various adult tissues) orimmature (sharing histologic features with fetal or embryonic tissue).

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding testicular tumors?

options.A: They may present as an abdominal lump.
options.B: Testicular biopsy is done to diagnose testicular carcinoma.
options.C: Seminomas metastasize predominantly via the lymphatic system.
options.D: Elevated tumor markers are found almost exclusively in non-seminomatous germ-cell tumors.

questions.explanation: There is no role of testicular biopsy in the diagnosis of testicular tumors. This is due to the risk ofseeding tumor cells onto the scrotal wall.In testicular tumors, the most common site of lymphatic spread is retroperitoneal lymph nodeswhich may present as an abdominal lump.Elevated tumor markers are found almost exclusively in non-seminomatous germ-cell tumors.Few seminomas may have elevated placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP) or beta-humanchorionic gonadotropin (HCG). Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) can be used as a marker of tumorbulk.Seminomas are radiosensitive tumors that metastasize via lymphatics. Non-germ-cell tumors arisefrom Sertoli or Leydig cells and follow a more benign course. Approximately only 10% aremalignant.

questions.question: A patient with a left-sided testicular tumor is being evaluated for metastasis. Which group oflymph nodes is most likely to get involved first?
questions.explanation: The first sites of metastasis in left-sided testicular tumors are the para-aortic lymph nodes.Testicular tumors metastasize first to the retroperitoneal nodes. Right-sided tumors metastasizeprimarily to the interaortocaval nodes. Left-sided tumors metastasize primarily to the leftpara-aortic nodes.1000Deep inguinal lymph nodes receive drainage from the perineum and lower extremity. Inguinallymph nodes may be involved if the testicular tumor spreads to the skin of the scrotum.

questions.question: A 25-year-old male patient presented with a hard painless testicular lump with a draggingsensation. The blood investigations showed raised AFP levels. Which of the following is leastlikely to be included, in further management of this case?

options.C: CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of a non-seminomatous germ cell tumor (NSGCT) of thetestis. Orchidectomy via a scrotal approach is not done due to fear of seeding the tumor in thescrotal skin. Instead, an inguinal approach is used.Raised AFP levels point towards the diagnosis of non-seminomatous germ cell tumor (NSGCT) ofthe testis.Ultrasound of the testis should be done in all suspected cases of testicular tumor. Tumormarkers (AFP, hCG, LDH) are measured for the staging of cancer. CT of the chest, abdomen, andpelvis is done to detect metastasis.Management of testicular tumorsStageStage ITumor confined to testisStage IINodal disease confined to nodes below the diaphragmStage IIINodal disease present above the diaphragmStage IVMetastasisNon-seminomatousOrchidectomy and chemotherapyOrchidectomy and chemotherapy Retroperitoneal lymph node dissection for residual diseaseOrchidectomy, radiotherapy,and chemotherapyIf residuallymph node disease is present, retroperitoneal lymph nodedissection is doneOrchidectomy and chemotheSeminomatousOrchidectomy and Active SurveillanceIf poor prognostic features* are seen, chemotherapy with a single agent, cisplatin for 1-2 cyclesOrchidectomy andradiotherapyIf residual lymph node disease is present, chemotherapyIn testicular tumors, the BEPregimen is followed withbleomycin, etoposide, cisplatin.*Poor prognostic factors following orchidectomy are:No decrease or change in tumor marker values or tumor sizePoorfollow up

questions.question: A patient with Stage I seminoma underwent an orchidectomy 3 months ago. On a follow-upvisit, elevated LDH levels were seen. What is the most appropriate line of management?

options.D: Regular scanning using CT and tumor marker measurement
